It would be amazing to get this into Mathlib. The PR has been open for a long time -- @Yuyang Zhao, could you summarise what needs to be done still?

The PR itself is still pretty much too large to review (and still has many missing doc strings). If there are parts that others could help with, explaining those details might be very helpful.
I've got on my near term to-do list to try and split a few things out, but I don't understand the maths proof, making it difficult to explain things
Two small changes split out from this: #17896 #17893
Next up is feat: add ConjRootClass #18693

@Ruben Van de Velde Thanks for working on this milestone project!
Can you please provide a bit more motivation for this PR? Is the quotient structure used a lot in places where working with minpoly or IsConjRoot directly would be painful?
Probably @Yuyang Zhao can give a better answer, but it's used in things like def toFinsupp : mapDomainFixed K L G ≃ₗ[L] ConjRootClass K G →₀ L in AlgebraicPart.lean

AlgebraicPart.lean still needs to be organized. Currently ConjRootClass is used to break the evaluation on mapDomainFixed into parts on each ConjRootClass, and finally the evaluation becomes summing over the roots of some polynomials.
I've been staring at the code for a bit. I don't have a good intuition yet for what mapDomainFixed is doing. My brain keeps thinking that G must be some (Galois) group...
Does your code follow some publicly available informal proof?
AlgebraicPart.lean follows the proof in Nathan Jacobson's Basic Algebra I.
Please add that to the module docstring.
Does Jacobson also use G to denote fields? I think I would already be helped a bit with understanding this file if G were called F_1 or K' or L_2 or something that looks a bit more like a field.

Ruben Van de Velde said:

Next up is feat: add ConjRootClass #18693

Fwiw, @Junyan Xu approved this
I'm still very doubtful that this is a useful abstraction for the proof of LW. Is it possible to also PR some other parts of the proof already?
One thing that seems orthogonal to all the other stuff is moving the Liouville files. So that can be done already, and will slightly simplify the diff of the overall PR.
Today I found that Chapter 17 (p. 203-208) of Lorenz's Algebra, Volume I contains a proof of Lindemann--Weierstrass.

That's more or less the standard proof at that level. It has the advantage over Baker's presentation (Transcendental Number Theory) to aim at L-W and do it directly, deriving Hermite and Lindemann as corollaries while Baker redoes the proof thrice.
I'm not sure I want to start looking at other proofs :)

Here is what Alan Baker says about this proof.
image.png
Fwiw, #29121 is adding some preliminary symmetricSubalgebra API for this
